data.title: Bad-jective
data.solution:
import re

line = input()
words = re.findall(r'[A-Za-z-]+', line)
lower_words = [word.lower() for word in words]

nouns = [input() for _ in range(int(input()))]

for noun in nouns:
    try:
        index = lower_words.index(noun)
    except ValueError:
        continue
    
    print(words[index - 1])
    exit()
data.statement:
You're provided with a sentence and a noun dictionary, and must find the adjective closest to the first noun in dictionary order in the sentence.

If multiple of the nouns from the dictionary appear in the sentence, <<you must use the first one in dictionary order>>. For example, if the dictionary defines {{apple}} then {{zebra}}, and the line {{The good zebra has eaten the bad apple.}} is provided, you must return {{bad}}, because {{apple}} comes before {{zebra}} in the dictionary.

Words are composed of latin letters (a-z) and optional dashes ({{-}}).

The adjective closest to a given noun phrase is always directly before the noun.
Words in the provided sentences contain uppercase and lowercase latin letters, and punctuations.
In the output, punctuations ({{.}}, {{!}}, {{,}}) must be removed, but case must be kept on the result.

Note that nouns in the dictionary are provided in lowercase, but they may be found with a different case in the sentence. For example, when {{day}} is provided in the dictionary, {{DAY}} or {{dAy}} may be provided in the sentence, and must be considered the same word.

Also note that nouns may be found with punctuations attached to it, e.g. {{day}} may appear as {{day!!}} or {{day.}}.

testCases.title: Basic test
testCases.testIn:
This is a beautiful beast.
1
beast

testCases.title: Basic test
testCases.testIn:
I am having an incredible moment.
1
moment

testCases.title: Multiple nouns in the dictionary
testCases.testIn:
I'm placing a green t-shirt into the washing machine.
2
pullover
t-shirt

testCases.title: Multiple nouns in the dictionary
testCases.testIn:
I put a single dollar into the vending machine.
3
dollar
euro
ruble

testCases.title: Multiple adjectives
testCases.testIn:
I see a blue striped bird on the tree over here!
4
bird
cat
dog
dragon

testCases.title: Multiple adjectives
testCases.testIn:
I've been given a green and crispy banknote for Christmas.
3
banknote
gift
guitar

testCases.title: Multiple adjectives with comma
testCases.testIn:
I guess I've always been the handsome, although weird, guy in the corridor of that school.
2
gal
guy

testCases.title: Multiple adjectives with comma
testCases.testIn:
It's quite a nice, however bumpy, terrain for riding my bicycle!
4
mountain
place
plateau
terrain

testCases.title: Case
testCases.testIn:
BURGERDAY IS THE MOST AWSUM DAY!!!

day
hour
month

testCases.title: Case
testCases.testIn:
y i no have any frEakIn anSweR!!

testCases.title: Multiple matches
testCases.testIn:
These wonderful two are a great match, don't you think?
2
match
two

testCases.title: Multiple matches
testCases.testIn:
Instead of what I was promised, I get fake headphones and a tiny cord! How unfair is that?!
2
cord
headphones

testCases.title: Final test
testCases.testIn:
This is based on the worst movie, and the most rage inducing, STUPID, game of all time!!
3
game
movie
thing

testCases.title: Final test
testCases.testIn:
I hate everything, including this ugly moron I have to call step dad and that bloody sTUPID GUY looking me up every single morning!!!
4
guy
moron
person
pervert

data.stubGenerator:
read line:string(512)
read count:int
loop count read noun:string(32)
write answer
data.inputDescription:
<<Line 1:>> A [[line]] including the noun and adjectives.
<<Line 2:>> A [[noun count]] of the nouns in the dictionary.
<<Next [[noun count]] lines:>> One noun per line (alphabetically sorted).
data.outputDescription: <<Line 1:>> The adjective closest to the first noun in the dictionary.

lastVersion.statementHTML:
Goal

You're provided with a sentence and a noun dictionary, and must find the adjective closest to the first noun in dictionary order in the sentence.

If multiple of the nouns from the dictionary appear in the sentence, you must use the first one in dictionary order. For example, if the dictionary defines apple then zebra, and the line The good zebra has eaten the bad apple. is provided, you must return bad, because apple comes before zebra in the dictionary.

Words are composed of latin letters (a-z) and optional dashes (-).

The adjective closest to a given noun phrase is always directly before the noun.
Words in the provided sentences contain uppercase and lowercase latin letters, and punctuations.
In the output, punctuations (., !, ,) must be removed, but case must be kept on the result.

Note that nouns in the dictionary are provided in lowercase, but they may be found with a different case in the sentence. For example, when day is provided in the dictionary, DAY or dAy may be provided in the sentence, and must be considered the same word.

Also note that nouns may be found with punctuations attached to it, e.g. day may appear as day!! or day..
Input
Line 1: A line including the noun and adjectives.
Line 2: A noun count of the nouns in the dictionary.
Next noun count lines: One noun per line (alphabetically sorted).
Output
Line 1: The adjective closest to the first noun in the dictionary.
Constraints
1 <= length(line) < 512
1 <= noun count
1 <= length(noun) < 32
Example
Input
This is a beautiful beast.
1
beast
Output
beautiful
